author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a very beautiful doll's-house; it was red brick with white windows, and it had real muslin curtains and a front door and a chimney.

author: Potter
text: It belonged to two Dolls called Lucinda and Jane; at least it belonged to Lucinda, but she never ordered meals.

author: Potter
text: Jane was the Cook; but she never did any cooking, because the dinner had been bought ready-made, in a box full of shavings.

author: Potter
text: There were two red lobsters and a ham, a fish, a pudding, and some pears and oranges.

author: Potter
text: They would not come off the plates, but they were extremely beautiful.

author: Potter
text: One morning Lucinda and Jane had gone out for a drive in the doll's perambulator.

author: Potter
text: There was no one in the nursery, and it was very quiet.

author: Potter
text: Presently there was a little scuffling, scratching noise in a corner near the fireplace, where there was a hole under the skirting-board.

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb put out his head for a moment, and then popped it in again.

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb was a mouse.

author: Potter
text: A minute afterwards, Hunca Munca, his wife, put her head out, too; and when she saw that there was no one in the nursery, she ventured out on the oilcloth under the coal-box.

author: Potter
text: The doll's-house stood at the other side of the fire-place.

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca went cautiously across the hearthrug.

author: Potter
text: They pushed the front door--it was not fast.

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca went upstairs and peeped into the dining-room.

author: Potter
text: Then they squeaked with joy!

author: Potter
text: Such a lovely dinner was laid out upon the table!

author: Potter
text: There were tin spoons, and lead knives and forks, and two dolly-chairs--all SO convenient!

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb set to work at once to carve the ham.

author: Potter
text: It was a beautiful shiny yellow, streaked with red.

author: Potter
text: The knife crumpled up and hurt him; he put his finger in his mouth.

author: Potter
text: "It is not boiled enough; it is hard.

author: Potter
text: You have a try, Hunca Munca."

author: Potter
text: Hunca Munca stood up in her chair, and chopped at the ham with another lead knife.

author: Potter
text: "It's as hard as the hams at the cheesemonger's," said Hunca Munca.

author: Potter
text: The ham broke off the plate with a jerk, and rolled under the table.

author: Potter
text: "Let it alone," said Tom Thumb; "give me some fish, Hunca Munca!"

author: Potter
text: Hunca Munca tried every tin spoon in turn; the fish was glued to the dish.

author: Potter
text: Then Tom Thumb lost his temper.

author: Potter
text: He put the ham in the middle of the floor, and hit it with the tongs and with the shovel--bang, bang, smash, smash!

author: Potter
text: The ham flew all into pieces, for underneath the shiny paint it was made of nothing but plaster!

author: Potter
text: Then there was no end to the rage and disappointment of Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca.

author: Potter
text: They broke up the pudding, the lobsters, the pears and the oranges.

author: Potter
text: As the fish would not come off the plate, they put it into the red-hot crinkly paper fire in the kitchen; but it would not burn either.

author: Potter
text: Tom Thumb went up the kitchen chimney and looked out at the top-- there was no soot.

author: Potter
text: While Tom Thumb was up the chimney, Hunca Munca had another disappointment.

author: Potter
text: She found some tiny canisters upon the dresser, labelled-- Rice--Coffee--Sago--but when she turned them upside down, there was nothing inside except red and blue beads.

author: Potter
text: Then those mice set to work to do all the mischief they could--especially Tom Thumb!

author: Potter
text: He took Jane's clothes out of the chest of drawers in her bedroom, and he threw them out of the top floor window.

author: Potter
text: But Hunca Munca had a frugal mind.

author: Potter
text: After pulling half the feathers out of Lucinda's bolster, she remembered that she herself was in want of a feather bed.

author: Potter
text: With Tom Thumbs's assistance she carried the bolster downstairs, and across the hearth-rug.

author: Potter
text: It was difficult to squeeze the bolster into the mouse- hole; but they managed it somehow.

author: Potter
text: Then Hunca Munca went back and fetched a chair, a book-case, a bird- cage, and several small odds and ends.

author: Potter
text: The book-case and the bird- cage refused to go into the mousehole.

author: Potter
text: Hunca Munca left them behind the coal-box, and went to fetch a cradle.

author: Potter
text: Hunca Munca was just returning with another chair, when suddenly there was a noise of talking outside upon the landing.

author: Potter
text: The mice rushed back to their hole, and the dolls came into the nursery.

author: Potter
text: What a sight met the eyes of Jane and Lucinda!

author: Potter
text: Lucinda sat upon the upset kitchen stove and stared; and Jane leant against the kitchen dresser and smiled--but neither of them made any remark.

author: Potter
text: The book-case and the bird-cage were rescued from under the coal- box--but Hunca Munca has got the cradle, and some of Lucinda's clothes.

author: Potter
text: She also has some useful pots and pans, and several other things.

author: Potter
text: The little girl that the doll's-house belonged to, said,--"I will get a doll dressed like a policeman!"

author: Potter
text: But the nurse said,--"I will set a mouse-trap!"

author: Potter
text: So that is the story of the two Bad Mice,--but they were not so very very naughty after all, because Tom Thumb paid for everything he broke.

author: Potter
text: He found a crooked sixpence under the hearth-rug; and upon Christmas Eve, he and Hunca Munca stuffed it into one of the stockings of Lucinda and Jane.

author: Potter
text: And very early every morning-- before anybody is awake--Hunca Munca comes with her dust-pan and her broom to sweep the Dollies' house!
